Section 206 of title 23, United States Code, is amended to define "snowmachine" as a motorized off-road vehicle intended for snow use and to establish guidelines for winter motorized access trails and funding estimation. The amendment to Section 206 of title 23, United States Code, defines "snowmachine" as a motorized off-road vehicle for snow use and sets guidelines for winter motorized access trails and funding estimation. The Department of the Treasury, the International Snowmobile Manufacturers Association, and other appropriate sources are involved in determining the amount of funds allocated to states for motorized access under the recreational trails program. The amendment to Section 206 of title 23, United States Code, defines "snowmachine" as a motorized off-road vehicle for snow use and sets guidelines for winter motorized access trails. States can use funds for activities that enhance winter motorized recreational trails on Bureau of Land Management or National Forest land and trails designed for diverse uses in other seasons. The amendment allows for the enhancement of winter motorized-use trails, including rerouting, designing new routes, linking existing systems, building facilities, and improving trail safety. The amendment aims to enhance winter motorized-use trails by establishing safety caches, marking trails, purchasing equipment, and mobilizing volunteers for maintenance and safety patrols. Public information campaigns are also included in the initiative. The Secretary will allocate $50,000 annually for public information campaigns promoting safe snowmachine use, consulting with snowmachine manufacturers and users for content design. The Secretary will allocate $50,000 annually for public information campaigns promoting safe snowmachine use, consulting with manufacturers, users, and the Advertising Council.
